verses.text: Then he brought me back to the entrance of the temple. There, I saw water flowing from beneath the threshold of the temple toward the east (for the temple faced east). The water was flowing beneath the south side of the temple, south of the altar.
verses.comment: This vision has both literal and spiritual meanings. Water often symbolizes life, purification, and the Holy Spirit, as in John 7:38. The temple is a source of life-giving water, prefiguring Christ as the true temple (John 2:19).

verses.text: He brought me out by way of the north gate and led me around outside to the outer gate by the way that faces east; and the water was trickling out on the south side.
verses.comment: The water's movement eastward and out of the temple signifies God's blessings flowing outward to the world.

verses.text: As the man went out east with a measuring line in his hand, he measured a thousand cubits, and then led me through the water; it was ankle-deep.
verses.comment: The progressive depth of the river symbolizes deeper spiritual growth and participation in God's life.

verses.text: Again he measured a thousand cubits and led me through the water; and it was now knee-deep. Again he measured a thousand and led me through the water; and it was waist-deep.
verses.comment: Each stage, the water grows in depth, representing a journey into spiritual maturity—hinting at sacraments and increasing union with God.

verses.text: Again he measured a thousand, and it was now a river that I could not cross, for the water had risen; it was deep enough to swim in, a river that could not be crossed.
verses.comment: The overwhelming abundance of water points to God's infinite grace. The river is uncrossable by human strength, highlighting dependence on divine grace.

verses.text: He said to me, 'Son of man, have you seen this?' Then he led me back to the bank of the river.
verses.comment: 'Son of man' is a term Jesus often uses to refer to Himself, reinforcing messianic connections (see Matthew 9:6).

verses.text: As I returned, I saw many trees on both sides of the river bank.
verses.comment: The trees parallel the tree of life, symbolizing ongoing participation in God's life. Trees recall Eden and the vision of the New Jerusalem in Revelation 22.

verses.text: He said to me, 'This water flows toward the eastern region and goes down into the Arabah, and when it enters the sea, the water becomes fresh.'
verses.comment: The water transforms barren land and brings life—a foreshadowing of spiritual renewal through the sacraments.

verses.text: Wherever the river flows, every living creature that swarms will live, and there will be many fish, for this water has come there, and the waters of the sea become fresh; so wherever the river goes, there will be life.
verses.comment: Allusion to new creation and the Gospel call to 'fishers of men.' Life abounds wherever God’s grace flows.

verses.text: Fishermen will stand beside it; from En-gedi to En-eglaim there will be a place for spreading nets. Its fish will be of many kinds, like the fish of the Great Sea, very many.
verses.comment: Symbolically refers to the universality of the Gospel and the gathering of many nations.

verses.text: But its swamps and marshes will not become fresh; they are to be left for salt.
verses.comment: Some reject the life-giving water, signifying those outside the fullness of God’s promise remain unhealed.

verses.text: And on the banks, on both sides of the river, there will grow all kinds of trees for food. Their leaves will not wither, nor will their fruit fail, but they will bear fresh fruit every month, because the water for them flows from the sanctuary. Their fruit will be for food, and their leaves for healing.
verses.comment: Echoes the tree of life—symbol of ongoing spiritual sustenance, Eucharistic overtones, and the healing power of God's grace.

verses.text: Thus says the Lord GOD: 'These are the boundaries of the land that you shall divide among the twelve tribes of Israel as their inheritance, with Joseph receiving two portions.'
verses.comment: The inheritance recalls God’s unbroken covenant with His people, expanded in the New Covenant.

verses.text: You shall divide equally what I swore to give to your fathers. This land shall fall to you as your inheritance.
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness to His promises and the passing of a spiritual inheritance linking Old and New Covenants.

verses.text: This shall be the boundary of the land: On the north side, from the Great Sea by way of Hethlon to Lebo-hamath, as far as Zedad;
verses.comment: Description of the physical borders of the promised inheritance.

verses.text: Berothah, Sibraim (which is between the border of Damascus and the border of Hamath), as far as Hazer-hatticon, which is on the border of Hauran.
verses.comment: Ezekiel recounts detailed boundaries to confirm God's restoration is real and trustworthy.

verses.text: So the boundary shall run from the sea to Hazar-enan, on the northern border of Damascus, with Hamath to the north. This shall be the north side.
verses.comment: Literal boundaries root the vision in history, showing God’s faithfulness.

verses.text: On the east side, from between Hauran and Damascus, along the Jordan, between Gilead and the land of Israel, down to the eastern sea. This shall be the east side.
verses.comment: Physical boundaries prefigure a greater spiritual inheritance later granted to all in Christ.

verses.text: On the south side, it shall run from Tamar as far as the waters of Meribah-kadesh, to the Brook of Egypt and on to the Great Sea. This shall be the south side.
verses.comment: References to Kadesh and Egypt recall the Exodus and entry into the promised land.

verses.text: On the west side, the Great Sea shall be the boundary to a point opposite Lebo-hamath. This shall be the west side.
verses.comment: The full boundaries reinforce the completeness of God’s promise.

verses.text: So you shall divide this land among yourselves according to the tribes of Israel.
verses.comment: Restoration of the land points to unity of God’s people, foreshadowing the gathering under one Shepherd (John 10:16).

verses.text: You shall allot it as an inheritance for yourselves, and for the foreigners who live among you and raise children among you. They shall be to you as native-born, and with you they shall share the inheritance among the tribes of Israel.
verses.comment: Inclusivity marks the promise; Gentiles are welcomed into God’s family, pointing to the Church's universality.

verses.text: In whatever tribe the foreigner resides, there you shall give him his inheritance, says the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: Final emphasis on unity and belonging in God's kingdom regardless of descent, fulfilled spiritually in Christ, who breaks down dividing walls (Eph. 2:14).
